author: Matthew Reynolds
title: Rainbow Six Siege's single-player Situations is part campaign, part training mode - Gaming
text: Rainbow Six Siege will have a single-player mode named Situations, a training destination to help ease players into the game, while also offering a challenge for seasoned players.While there is no specific storyline like a traditional campaign, each of the 11 missions will be introduced by Six (played by American Horror Story actress Angela Bassett), explaining each Situation you face, from hostage rescue to bomb defusal. © Ubisoft Each mission is focused on a different Operative class and multiplayer map, teaching players while tackling specific scenarios.One has you rescue a hostage and taking them to a checkpoint, another is clearing an aeroplane of armed assailants, while another is defending an informant from incoming waves."As the game does have destruction and Operators, there's a ton of things to learn," senior environmental artist Chris Hendry told Digital Spy. © Ubisoft / Digital Spy "These Situations are pretty much to get the player in there to learn the game, to experience all the Operators, the maps, the drone, the gadgets."There's so much content to look at, and the Situations is a good way to address that."Unlike competitive play or Terrorist Hunt - which has a reactive and changing intelligence in every match - the enemy and objective positions in Situations are more predefined.This gives it a similar feel to older Rainbow Six games, or Modern Warfare 2's Spec Ops mode, and helps encourage players to learn maps and routes. © Ubisoft / Digital Spy For further replayability, each mission has three optional objectives, and ramps up the challenge with additional difficulty settings that make it harder to survive."It's not easy to finish a game with 50 health on Realistic [mode], when you have to defuse however many C4s and [complete] however many objectives," Hendry said. "You get hurt very quick, so it's a pretty good challenge."Players can also earn Renown - the game's currency to unlock new Operators and weapon attachments - from completing missions and objectives, which can be used in other modes, and vice versa.It was suggested that more missions would be available after the game's release. © Ubisoft / Digital Spy Rainbow Six Siege was recently given a delay until December, to allow for closed beta feedback to be properly implemented.Publisher Ubisoft recently announced that all maps for the game would be free after launch.As well as player-versus-player matches, Rainbow Six Siege will see the return of Terrorist Hunt mode.Our hands-on with the tactical destruction-filled shooter Rainbow Six SiegeCheck out our most anticipated games of October, one of many videos in Digital Spy's dedicated Gaming YouTube channel.
